descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Michael Jordan, who used to destroy the Cavaliers nearly every time he played them, scored 18 points in his first game back with Washington in Cleveland's 94-75 win Tuesday night over the Wizards.
article.headline: Jordan struggles to find rhythm, Cavs feast
article.linkText: Wizard misery: Cavs cruise past struggling MJ
article.story:
CLEVELAND (AP) -- Michael Jordan didn't miss any of the shots he took at his teammates. "I think we stink," he said. Jordan, who used to destroy the Cavaliers nearly every time he played them, scored 18 points in his first game back with Washington as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Wizards 94-75 Tuesday night. Jordan came in shooting just 40.4 percent -- a career-low -- and went only 9-of-24 from the floor and didn't attempt a free throw in 31 minutes. He added four rebounds and five assists before sitting out the final 4:33 with the Wizards down by 20. But more troubling to Jordan was that none of his teammates stepped up. "I don't see anyone covering my back as everyone probably expected me to cover theirs," he said. "That's something I'm not going to live too much with. These guys are young enough to step forward and make an effort. "The disappointing part is that there are guys capable of doing it and they just aren't for whatever reason. If they can't make a basket or two, so what? At least they shouldn't lack on the defensive end or rebounding. I don't sense that urgency coming from this team." Ricky Davis scored 14 of his 18 points in the fourth quarter, and Lamond Murray had 14 points and 10 rebounds for the Cavs, who won their third straight at home. A sellout crowd of 20,562 came to Gund Arena to see Jordan, who gave the fans a few thrills but had another off night. "He doesn't show it, but you know deep down that he's frustrated," said Cavs guard Bimbo Coles. "He's not winning. He's playing with young guys and he's not shooting well. That's got to be tough." Jordan certainly wasn't the old Jordan, who averaged 31.6 points in his first 80 games against the Cavaliers and eliminated them four times in the playoffs. It was against Cleveland in 1989 that he made "The Shot" over Craig Ehlo in the decisive Game 5 to advance the Chicago Bulls. He also scored 69 points -- his career-high -- on March 28, 1990, against Cleveland. But also had just 8 points in a loss on March 12, 1986, the last time he scored in single digits. Jordan isn't making many shots these day, and his supporting cast isn't offering much help. Richard Hamilton shot 3-of-13 and had 13 points and Christian Laettner 10 for the Wizards, who shot just 34 percent from the field and dropped to 3-10. "I'm not going to make excuses," Jordan said in an overcrowded Wizards locker room after he decided to hold his postgame news conference there. "I missed layups. I missed easy, wide-open shots. But that doesn't mean it should sink our boat." Wizards coach Doug Collins was just as upset as Jordan. "We were lifeless," he said. "I knew it before the game. I told the assistant coaches, 'We'll be down by 20 before the break'." Jumaine Jones added 15 points, Andre Miller 14 and Chris Mihm had 13 points and 10 rebounds for Cleveland. Cavs coach John Lucas was as nervous as his players, some of whom had posters of Jordan on their bedroom walls. "My only concern is that he loves Cleveland," Lucas said before the game. "Even though he's old and all. An old dog wakes up in familiar places." It took the old dog a while to warm up. Jordan missed four of his first five shots, including a short jumper and layup off an alley-oop in a five-second span. However, he helped bring the Wizards back from a 20-point deficit. Jordan drilled a 16-footer, banked in a 10-footer and hit two short turnarounds as Washington closed the half with an 18-6 run to pull to 48-40 at halftime. The Wizards got within two in the third, but the Cavs took an eight-point lead and quickly built it back to 20 as Davis scored eight straight points and Coles chipped in with two straight baskets. Moments later, Jordan called it a night. "Right now, we're not accepting the challenge and that's very frustrating," he said.

Game notes
One fan held up a sign saying, "70?" when Jordan took the floor. ... Jordan recorded the first triple-double in All-Star game history at the Gund in 1997. ... When he was coaching in Philadelphia, Lucas introduced a teenage Kobe Bryant to Jordan. "Kobe said, 'Mr. Jordan, nice to meet you'," Lucas recalled. "I said, 'Kobe, you can't do that, you're going to be in the league next year'. Michael just laughed." ... Wizards rookie Brendan Haywood got his first career points on a slam dunk with 1:27 left in the first quarter. Haywood played his first game after starting the season on the injured list with torn ligament in his left thumb.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
